Description:
CRO: A professional who assesses, collects, organizes, preserves, maintains control over, and provides access to information determined to have long-term value.
DCITE: Institution tasked with responsibility to generate/disseminate copies of the resource in either electronic or print form.
DDI: Distributing/disseminating the data to users and making them available for reuse. Maps to 'Distributor' in DataCite.
Creation and/or presentation of a published research object, such as books, journal articles, and other publications like technical documentation, web sites, code, ontologies, or data models.
Includes literature searches and contributions to review activities (systematic reviews, scoping reviews, etc.)
Creation and/or presentation of a published research object, such as books, journal articles, and other publications like technical documentation, web sites, code, ontologies, or data models.

Examination of software code to identify build-breaking changes prior to acceptance into a codebase.
CRediT: Programming, software development; designing computer programs; implementation of the computer code and supporting algorithms; testing of existing code components.
Activities to obtain physical objects for research purposes or to add to a collection.
Coordination of research dissemination through popular media and the press, as well as community outreach and liaising of project directly to the community.

A communication role which involves the dynamic relational process that facilitates communication, interaction, involvement, and exchange between an organization and a community for a range of social and organizational outcomes.

Algorithm development and implementation of software in a computer programming language.
CRediT: Programming, software development; designing computer programs; implementation of the computer code and supporting algorithms; testing of existing code components.
DDI: Creating and maintaining software needed at any stage of the data life cycle.
A person responsible for the preservation of artistic and cultural artifacts.

CRO: Person with knowledge of how to access, troubleshoot, or otherwise field issues related to the resource.
DCITE: Person with knowledge of how to access, troubleshoot, or otherwise field issues related to the resource
DDI: Individual, or organization that may be reached to obtain data-related information. Maps to 'ContactPerson' in DataCite.

CRO: A high-level classification of the diverse roles performed in the work leading to a published research output in the sciences. Its purpose to provide transparency in contributions to scholarly published work, to enable improved systems of attribution, credit, and accountability.
DCITE: Any person or institution making a significant contribution to the development and/or maintenance of the resource, but whose contribution does not “fit” other controlled vocabulary for contributorType.
DDI: Use if the role is known but not in the list. Can be mapped to the roles 'RelatedPerson', 'Producer', and 'Work Package Leader' in DataCite.
The organization of the different elements needed to implement a study.

CRO: Management activities to annotate, maintain, research, and preserve physical objects to maximize their use for research and education now and into the future.
DCITE: Person tasked with reviewing, enhancing, cleaning, or standardizing metadata and the associated data submitted for storage, use, and maintenance within a data centre or repository
DDI: Performing operations that result in changes to the data, including data cleaning, editing, post- harmonization, etc. Maps to 'DataCurator' in DataCite.
CRediT: Management activities to annotate (produce metadata), scrub data and maintain research data (including software code, where it is necessary for interpreting the data itself) for initial use and later re-use.

CRO: A role that encompasses effective and efficient operation and usage of data, including, but not limited to management, handling, or manipulation.
DCITE: Person (or organisation with a staff of data managers, such as a data centre) responsible for maintaining the finished resource.
DDI: Development and execution of architectures, policies, practices and procedures to handle data at any stage of its life cycle. Includes processes and activities related to the selection, organization and integration of data, their annotation, as well as their publication and preservation so that the data maintain their value over time, and remain available for reuse.
DDI: Acquiring data and supporting documentation from potential contributors for further preservation and/or dissemination.
The compiling of information with intent to prepare combined datasets for data processing.

CRO: The process of gathering and measuring data, information or any variables of interest in a standardized and established manner that enables the collector to answer or test hypothesis and evaluate outcomes of the particular collection.
DCITE: Person/institution responsible for finding, gathering/collecting data under the

guidelines of the author(s) or Principal Investigator (PI)
DDI: Activities relating to the process of gathering data in an established, systematic fashion that enables answering the stated research questions, testing hypotheses, and evaluating outcomes. Maps to 'DataCollector' in DataCite.
The process of inputting data into a computerized form.
The process of combining data from different sources to provide a standardized or unified view.

CRO: The process of creating a data model for an information system by applying certain formal techniques.
DDI: Creating a data model based on an analysis of data objects and their relationships, data properties, as well as data flows and processes. It is often the first step in database creation, tool and standards development, etc., and typically involves a progression from a conceptual model to a logical model, and then to a physical schema

DDI: Planning or using specific techniques to preserve the anonymity of individual or other entities that the data refer to. For example, anonymization, pseudonymization, or removal of direct and indirect identifiers.
A procedure intended to verify the efficiency and reliability of data.

CRO: The process of creating data standards, which are the rules by which data are described and recorded in order to share, exchange, and understand data. Examples include development of an ontology, terminology, code lists, etc.
DDI: Developing models for the structure and distribution of data and metadata in fixed, predictable formats. For example, the DATS
(Data Tag Suite) for describing biomedical data, the Data Documentation Initiative (DDI) for describing social, behavioral, economic, and health sciences data, etc.
Aggregation, integration, manipulation of data.
Verification, whether as a part of the activity or separate, of the overall replication/reproducibility of results/experiments and other research outputs.
A role usually within the Information Technology department, charged with the creation, maintenance, backups, querying, tuning, user rights assignment and security of an organization's databases.

CRO: A role charged with conceptualization, design, development and marketing of complex equipment.
DDI: Creating and maintaining equipment needed at any stage of the data life cycle.
A role that includes the formal endeavor to ensure that digital information of continuing value remains accessible, trustworthy, and usable.
A communication role in which one records the details of an event, a process, a workflow, etc.

A person who oversees the details related to the publication format of the resource.
Preparation, creation and/or presentation of the published work by those from the original research group, specifically critical review, commentary or revision – including pre- or post-publication stages.

CRO: A role in which a person participates in the transfer of knowledge and skills, through teaching, development of educational materials or curriculum, through program development or other means.
DDI: Imparting information and/or instructions to improve the recipient's performance or to help attain a required level of knowledge or skills related to research or research data. For example, training interviewers, translators, data archivists, or data analysts.
An educational role in which knowledge and skills is transferred through teaching.
An educational role in which a person develops educational or training materials that are intended to transfer knowledge, for use in a classroom, indpendent learning or other settings.
An educational role in which a person participates in the development of an educational program, designed for learners to achieve a set of compentencies around a given topic or area of focus.
A person that is responsible for operating equipment or instrumentation and/or that ensures equipment is well-maintained, properly configured, and safely functional.
Evaluation is a systematic method for collecting, analyzing, and using information to answer questions about projects, policies and programs, particularly about their effectiveness and efficiency.

CRO: Preparation, creation and/or presentation of figures for a manuscript, presentation or other use.
CRediT: Preparation, creation and/or presentation of the published work, specifically visualization/data presentation.
DDI: Representing data, analysis results, or other information as a chart, image or animation, to aid in the understanding of their meaning.
DDI: Searching for, and/or obtaining financial or other type of support for a program or project.

DDI: Providing financial support to a program or project, usually by an organization or government. Funding is made for a specific purpose for which the successful applicant must often account in full.

CRO: A communication role that utilizes the art or profession of using design elements (such as typography and images) to convey information, create visualizations, or create an effect.
DDI: Combining text and images to support and enhance content, and make it visually appealing and user-friendly.
A methodology role that involves development of information that suggests how something should be done.
An information technology systems role that specifically focuses on the computer hardware, the physical components of a computer system.

Typically, the organisation allowing the resource to be available on the internet through the provision of its hardware/software/operating support.
DDI: Housing, servicing, and maintaining data and, usually, the accompanying metadata or related documentation. Maps to to 'HostingInstitution' in DataCite.
A role that involves the development, management, and use of computer-based information systems.
Contribution to the basic, underlying framework or features of a system or organization.
A person that is responsible for usage of instrumentation, such as equipment or devices, or instruments like a survey or questionnaire.
A role related to creations of the mind, such as inventions; literary and artistic works; designs; and symbols, names and images used in commerce. from.

Concept: IT hardware systems design and implementation
Description: A role that includes the design and implementation of the physical components of a computer system.
creditRoleOntology: IT hardware systems design and implementation role

Description: A role in which one provides a summary of a research output, such as a journal article, that is understandable by a lay person or non- expert audience.
creditRoleOntology: lay synthesis of research output role

Description: A communication role that involves the activity, set of institutions, and processes for creating, communicating, delivering, and exchanging offerings that have value for customers, clients, partners, and society at large.

The annotation of data with descriptive information that describes the data (metadata), with the goal of making the data more usuable or reusable for future use.
DCITE: Person tasked with reviewing, enhancing, cleaning, or standardizing metadata and the associated data submitted for storage, use, and maintenance within a data centre or repository
CRediT: Management activities to annotate (produce metadata), scrub data and maintain research data (including software code, where it is necessary for interpreting the data itself) for initial use and later re-use.

DDI: Generating data documentation. For example, a study description covering study rationale, methodology, and other characteristics of the dataset as a whole; variable-level documentation (labels, frequencies, question text); references to study-related materials or publications, etc.
A communication role that encompasses facilitate co-operation between people or organizations.

Creation and/or presentation of the published work, specifically writing the initial draft (including substantive translation).
CRediT: Preparation, creation and/or presentation of the published work, specifically writing the initial draft (including substantive translation).

A communication role that involves development or production of materials, such as brochures, websites, flyers, presentations, etc., for the purposes of promotion of a entity, like a project, group or organization.
party that owns the resource

Role that involves identifying eligible participants, explaining the study to potential participants, recruiting an adequate sample based on study goals and design, obtaining informed consent/maintaining ethical standards, and retaining participants until study completion.

Policy development generally involves research, analysis, consultation and synthesis of information to produce recommendations for action by an individual or an organization. It should also involve an evaluation of options against a set of criteria used to assess each option.
Set of activities aimed at prolonging the life of a record.

key party responsible for gathering information and conducting research
CRediT: Conducting a research and investigation process, specifically performing the experiments, or data/evidence collection.
CRediT: Acquisition of the financial support for the project leading to this publication.
Typically a person or organisation responsible for the artistry and form of a media product.

An infrastructure role that is accountable for management and coordination of a program, to help achieve the program goals.
DCITE: Person officially designated as manager of a project. Project may consist of one or many project teams and sub-teams.
CRediT: Management and coordination responsibility for the research activity planning and execution.
Planning, management, and monitoring of projects.

CRO: Person on the membership list of a designated project/project team.
DCITE: Person on the membership list of a designated project/project team.
DCITE: A person involved in analyzing data or the results of an experiment or formal study. May indicate an intern or assistant to one of the authors who helped with research but who was not so “key” as to be listed as an author.
DCITE: Typically refers to a group of individuals with a lab, department, or division; the group has a particular, defined focus of activity.
DDI: Person that contributes and participates as a member in a designated project or project team. Maps to 'ProjectMember' in DataCite.
DDI: An individual involved in analyzing the data or the study results, but whose role is to help with the research rather than be a creator. For example, a researcher may seek, and find additional data from another source and correlate it to the study or experiment that is being conducted. Maps to 'Researcher' in DataCite.
DDI: Group of individuals involved in the research. Maps to 'ResearchGroup' in DataCite.
A methodology role that involves creation of a detailed plan of a scientific or medical experiment, treatment, or procedure.
party who published the resource
Institution/organisation officially appointed by a Registration Authority to handle specific tasks within a defined area of responsibility.

DCITE: A standards-setting body from which Registration Agencies obtain official recognition and guidance.
DDI: A standards-setting body from which Registration Agencies obtain official recognition and guidance. For example, the International DOI Foundation (IDF) serves as the registration authority for the International Standards Organization (ISO) in the area/domain of Digital Object Identifiers.
Manage regulatory and compliance issues for the research project.
A person without a specifically defined role in the development of the resource, but who is someone the author wishes to recognize.

The tasks that go into determining the needs or conditions to meet for a new or altered software product or project, taking account of the possibly conflicting requirements of the various stakeholders, analyzing, documenting, validating and managing software or system requirements.
CRediT: Ideas; formulation or evolution of overarching research goals and aims.
CRediT: Provision of study materials, reagents, materials, patients, laboratory samples, animals, instrumentation, computing resources, or other analysis tools.

DCITE: Person or institution owning or managing property rights, including intellectual property rights over the resource
DDI: Owning property rights, including intellectual property rights over the resource. Maps to 'RightsHolder' in DataCite.
DDI: Managing licenses for distributed data, tools, and other research materials on behalf of the rights holder.

Creation of high-level structures of a software system.
CRediT: Programming, software development; designing computer programs; implementation of the computer code and supporting algorithms; testing of existing code components.

Creation of low-level software component and algorithm design.
CRediT: Programming, software development; designing computer programs; implementation of the computer code and supporting algorithms; testing of existing code components.

Creation of software documentation.
CRediT: Programming, software development; designing computer programs; implementation of the computer code and supporting algorithms; testing of existing code components.

Systematic application of scientific and technological knowledge, methods, and experience to the design, implementation, testing, and documentation of software.
CRediT: Programming, software development; designing computer programs; implementation of the computer code and supporting algorithms; testing of existing code components.

An information technology systems role that specifically focuses on the computer software, the non-tangible executable component of a computer.
CRediT: Programming, software development; designing computer programs; implementation of the computer code and supporting algorithms; testing of existing code components.

Verification that software meets requirements; validation that software meets users' needs, identification of software bugs, assessment of software performance and usability.
CRediT: Programming, software development; designing computer programs; implementation of the computer code and supporting algorithms; testing of existing code components.

Person or organisation that issued a contract or under the auspices of which a work has been written, printed, published, developed, etc.
DCITE: Person or organisation that issued a contract or under the auspices of which a work has been written, printed, published, developed, etc.
DDI: Providing support for research or for other work or activities. Includes in-kind support, for example, providing staff time, facilities or instrumentation. Maps to 'Sponsor' in DataCite.
A methodology role that involves the development or creation of an established or prescribed methods to be followed routinely for the performance of designated operations or in designated situations.

The process of creating standards, which aare an established norm or requirement in regard to technical systems. It is usually a formal document that establishes uniform engineering or technical criteria, methods, processes, and practices.

CRO: Statistical aspects of research, including data collection, organization, analysis, interpretation and presentation of data from surveys and experiments
CRediT: Application of statistical, mathematical, computational, or other formal techniques to analyse or synthesize study data.

CRO: Detailed design of study components including data collection, analysis, and dissemination.
DDI: Describing the rationale, and putting together a specific plan for conducting a study or research project.

CRO: Oversight and leadership responsibility for the research activity planning and execution, including mentorship external to the core team.
CRediT: Management and coordination responsibility for the research activity planning and execution.
CRediT: Oversight and leadership responsibility for the research activity planning and execution, including mentorship external to the core team.
DCITE: Person officially designated as head of project team or sub- project team instrumental in the work necessary to development of the resource.
DCITE: A Work Package is a recognized data product, not all of which is included in publication. The package, instead, may include notes, discarded documents, etc. The Work Package Leader is responsible for ensuring the comprehensive contents, versioning, and availability of the Work Package during the development of the resource.
DCITE: Designated administrator over one or more groups/teams working to produce a resource or over one or more steps of a development process.
DDI: Person officially designated as head of a project, or subproject team that carries out the work for developing a resource. The project leader remains closely involved in the work performed throughout the life of the project. Maps to 'ProjectLeader' in DataCite.
DDI: Overseeing one or more individuals or teams in their work. Maps to 'Supervisor' in DataCite.
Creation or refinement of a survey or questionnaire, a list of questions aimed at extracting specific data from a particular group of people.
A software systems role that involves maintenance and operation of a computer system and/or network.

CRediT: Management and coordination responsibility for the research activity planning and execution.
CRO: Coordination of diverse team members, often across different disciplines and locations.
DCITE: Person officially designated as manager of a project. Project may consist of one or many project teams and sub-teams.
DDI: Person officially designated as manager of a project. This function normally has more administrative responsibilities than actual work involvement. Maps to 'ProjectManager' in DataCite.
A documentation role that involves preparation of instruction manuals, journal articles, and other supporting documents to communicate complex and technical information more easily.
One who is proficient in the relevant skill and technique, with a relatively practical understanding of the theoretical principles.

A methodology role that involves the creation or refinement of a manner or method by which an activity is performed.
CRediT: Development or design of methodology; creation of models.
DDI: Developing guidelines or protocols for the methods used to conduct the study, and to process and analyze the data. For example, directions and instructions for collecting data, conducting interviews, translating questionnaires, input harmonization, using weights, etc.
DDI: Conceiving and planning for the data collection instrument(s). May include the operationalization of concepts into questions and indicators, instrument testing, forward translation and subsequent changes in the master instrument(s), as well as designing and testing other types of data collection instruments than survey questionnaires.

CRO: Translating words or text from one language to another.
DDI: Expressing the content of text or speech in a different language than the original language used. For example, questionnaire or study report translation.
party who uses the resource
CRediT: Verification, whether as a part of the activity or separate, of the overall replication/reproducibility of results/experiments and other research outputs.

CRO: Creation or refinement of a website, a set of related web pages served from a single web domain.
DDI: Creating and maintaining a website related to the data. May include web design, building a user interface, network security configuration, etc.
A method or steps that maintain, update content, clean up, or repair a website.

A Work Package is a recognized data product, not all of which is included in publication. The package, instead, may include notes, discarded documents, etc. The Work Package Leader is responsible for ensuring the comprehensive contents, versioning, and availability of the Work Package during the development of the resource.
